🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠, 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 & 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 — 𝐒𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐟𝐢𝐞𝐝!If you're working with inheritance in Java or automation frameworks like Selenium, this is one of the most powerful concepts👇🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 ✅ Definition: Redefining a method of the parent class in the child class🔹 Key Rules:1. Method signature must be exactly the same2. Return type must be the same or covariant3. Access modifier can be more permissive (not more restrictive)4. Happens only in inheritance5. Enables runtime polymorphism⚡ 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 (𝐚.𝐤.𝐚 𝐋𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠) ✅ The method to execute is decided at runtime 🔹 Used when:1. You're overriding methods2. Based on object type, not the reference type📌 | 𝐉𝐚𝐯𝐚 𝐝𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐭 𝐫𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐰𝐡𝐢𝐜𝐡 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐝𝐞𝐧 𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐞𝐱𝐞𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐞 𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐨𝐛𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐭𝐲𝐩𝐞🛠️ 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 ✅ Occurs when a parent class reference is used to call an overridden method in the child class✅ Example: Run-Time Polymorphism (via Method Over-riding) java𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑮𝒖𝒆𝒔𝒕"); }}𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒆𝒙𝒕𝒆𝒏𝒅𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏"); }}𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑻𝒆𝒔𝒕 { 𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒔𝒕𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒄 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒎𝒂𝒊𝒏(𝑺𝒕𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒈[] 𝒂𝒓𝒈𝒔) { 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋 = 𝒏𝒆𝒘 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏(); // 👈 𝑹𝒆𝒇𝒆𝒓𝒆𝒏𝒄𝒆 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆: 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 | 𝑶𝒃𝒋𝒆𝒄𝒕 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆:𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋.𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆(); // 👈 𝑪𝒂𝒍𝒍𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏’𝒔 𝒎𝒆𝒕𝒉𝒐𝒅 𝒂𝒕 𝒓𝒖𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒎𝒆(𝒅𝒚𝒏𝒂𝒎𝒊𝒄 𝒃𝒊𝒏𝒅𝒊𝒏𝒈) }}

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is Exception Handling?Exception handling is a way to manage errors that occur while a program is running. Instead of stopping the entire program when an error happens, exception handling lets you control what should happen when something goes wrong.🌟 Why is it important?It helps prevent the program from crashing.It allows the program to continue running even after an error.It shows clear and friendly error messages to the user.It makes debugging and fixing issues easier.🌟 How does it work?You write the code that might cause an error inside a special block. If an error happens, another block will handle it. This keeps the program safe and avoids unexpected crashes.🌟 Key Terms:Try: The block where you write the code that might cause an error.Catch: The block where you handle the error if it occurs.Finally: A block that runs no matter what—whether there was an error or not.Throw: Used to create custom errors or exceptions.Throws: Used to declare exceptions that a method might cause.

Today's Learning Journey 📕: Stacks in JavaToday, I explored one of the fundamental data structures— the Stack.**What is a Stack?** A Stack is a linear data structure that follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle. The last element added is the first one to be removed. Think of it like a stack of plates — you add to the top and remove from the top.**Why It's Important?** Stacks are used in many areas like function calls, expression evaluation, undo features in editors, and more. Understanding how they work is essential for solving real-world problems and mastering algorithms.**Key Takeaways:** 1. Core Operations: push(), pop(), peek(), and isEmpty()2. Implementation: Explored Java's built-in Stack class and also implemented it manually using arrays and linked lists. 3. Applications: Helps build intuition for recursion, backtracking, and parsing tasks.#Java #DataStructures #Stack #CodingJourney #Programming #TechLearning

كلامنا النهاردة عن  JVM، JRE، وJDK... مين هم أبطال القصة؟في عالم جافا، عندنا 3 شخصيات رئيسية، وكل واحدة ليها دور مهم جدًا:يلا نغوص سوا في عالم JVM، JRE، وJDK ونفهم كل واحدة فيهم بتشتغل إزاي؟ 🧠 أولاً: JVM – Java Virtual Machine ده هو قلب القصة.تخيله كأنه "المترجم الذكي" اللي بياخد الـ Bytecode (ملفات .class) ويحوّله لحاجة الجهاز يفهمها وظيفته:يقرأ ملفات .class اللي بيطلّعها الـ Compilerيفسرها سطر بسطر ويحوّلها لـ Machine Codeيتعامل مع نظام التشغيل (Windows / Linux / macOS)بيشتغل على أي جهاز فيه JVM → عشان كده جافا بتشتغل في كل مكان!أنواعه: كل نظام تشغيل ليه JVM خاصة بيه. الكود بيشتغل على أي نظام بشرط يكون فيه JVM.🌱 ثانيًا: JRE – Java Runtime Environment📦 دي البيئة اللي بيعيش فيها برنامج جافا بعد ما تكتبه.بتتكوّن من:JVMJava Class Libraries (زي System.out, ArrayList, Scanner, …)وظيفتها: تشغّل برامج جافا الجاهزة، بس مش ينفع تكتبي أو ترجمي كود جديد بيها. مثال: لو عندك برنامج جاهز وعايزة تشغّليه → محتاجة JRE فقط.🔧 ثالثًا: JDK – Java Development Kitدي العُدّة الكاملة لأي مطوّر/مطوّرة جافا.بتحتوي على:✅ كل مكونات الـ JRE✅ أدوات التطوير (Dev Tools):javac: لتحويل الكود لـ Bytecodejava: لتشغيل البرامجjavadoc: لتوليد التوثيقDebuggers: لتتبع الأخطاءوظيفتها:كتابة الكودترجمتهتشغيلهاختباره يعني باختصار: لو هتشتغل على مشروع جافا → لازم تنزّل الـ JDK الـ JRE لوحده مش هيكفي.لو وصلت لحد هنا، شاركني: أنت كنت عارف الفرق بينهم قبل كده؟ ولا دي أول مرة الصورة توضح؟ 😊👇hashtag#Java hashtag#JVM hashtag#JRE hashtag#JDK hashtag#LearnJava hashtag#Backend hashtag#ProgrammingBasics hashtag#لينكدإن

Maroš Varchola is a 22 year old founder based in Slovakia that builds software that processes tens of thousands of euros a month. 💸Reconciliation is the process of matching transaction data with business processes, like outgoing invoices. In the past reconciliation has been a messy, non-deterministic process, but things are changing. ISO20022 is the "HTTP" protocol of money. As banks adopt improved data formats around financial data like ISO20022, transaction matching becomes much simpler: end to end tracking IDs make reconciliation deterministic and unambigious.Maroš contributed end to end ID support to iso20022.js and uses it in production to perfectly reconcile tens of thousands of euros of invoices a month. iso20022.js is the leading library that allows developers to interact with the modern banking system. With almost a dozen contributors, it has a bigger engineering team than most startups!

🚀 Lesson Learned: Read the Docs, Save Hours! 📚⏱️While working on my final year project — a fake profile detection system using Instagram data — I spent nearly 2-3 hours trying to integrate Apify's Instagram scraper using raw API calls, handling URLs, tokens, HTTP errors… the usual grind. 😓Everything looked right, but I was constantly getting empty or default responses. Just when the frustration started to build up, I took a step back and finally did what I should have done first — I read the official Apify documentation.And guess what? 💡Turns out, Apify provides a clean and powerful Python SDK (apify-client) that makes the whole process so much easier and more reliable. Instead of manually hitting endpoints, handling dataset IDs, and parsing results, I could just:✅ Initialize the client ✅ Call the actor with run_input ✅ Iterate over results like a breezeThis experience reminded me of something simple but powerful:“Documentation is not optional — it’s a superpower.” 💥Next time, before diving into hours of trial-and-error, I’ll definitely start by checking the docs first. It’s a small habit that saves massive time.

After years of building backend systems with Spring Boot, if there’s one thing that keeps standing out—it’s that a well-designed API is more than just a contract. It’s the front door to your system, the layer everyone interacts with, and the first place things break if you’re not careful.I still remember working on an old monolithic app—huge codebase, tight coupling, and one giant controller doing everything. Refactoring that into clean, RESTful microservices was like fresh air. Suddenly, each service had its own purpose, its own voice—and scaling became a breeze.A few REST essentials I’ve come to love along the way:  @RestController – Making it easy to return clean, structured JSON without all the XML baggage. @GetMapping / @PostMapping / @PutMapping – Routes that make sense and read like documentation. @PreAuthorize – Because security isn't optional, especially when you're exposing data to the world. @FeignClient – Let your services talk like friends, not strangers.What I’ve learned is: REST APIs aren’t just about exposing data—they’re about designing systems that are secure, reliable, and future-proof. Whether it’s handling failures with proper status codes, paginating heavy data, or versioning APIs to avoid breaking consumers—it’s all part of the craft.If you’ve ever refactored an API, migrated from SOAP, or turned a legacy app into lean microservices, you know the challenges (and the satisfaction).What’s your biggest lesson or “aha!” moment with REST APIs? Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is a Package?A package is like a folder in your computer that helps you organize your Java files (classes, interfaces, etc.).🌟 Why do we use Packages?To organize code neatlyTo avoid name conflicts (two classes can have the same name if they are in different packages)To reuse code easilyTo make project structure clean and easy to manage🌟 Types of Packages:Built-in packages – already available in Java (like java.util, java.io)User-defined packages – created by us to group our own classes🌟 How to Create and Use a Package?You create a package using the package keyword.You use it by importing it with the import keyword.🌟 Think of it like this:Your computer has folders (packages)Inside folders, you have files (Java classes)You can open and use files from any folder using the correct path (importing the package)

🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠, 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 & 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 — 𝐒𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐟𝐢𝐞𝐝!If you're working with inheritance in Java or automation frameworks like Selenium, this is one of the most powerful concepts👇🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 ✅ Definition: Redefining a method of the parent class in the child class🔹 Key Rules:1. Method signature must be exactly the same2. Return type must be the same or covariant3. Access modifier can be more permissive (not more restrictive)4. Happens only in inheritance5. Enables runtime polymorphism⚡ 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 (𝐚.𝐤.𝐚 𝐋𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠) ✅ The method to execute is decided at runtime 🔹 Used when:1. You're overriding methods2. Based on object type, not the reference type📌 | 𝐉𝐚𝐯𝐚 𝐝𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐭 𝐫𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐰𝐡𝐢𝐜𝐡 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐝𝐞𝐧 𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐞𝐱𝐞𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐞 𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐨𝐛𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐭𝐲𝐩𝐞🛠️ 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 ✅ Occurs when a parent class reference is used to call an overridden method in the child class✅ Example: Run-Time Polymorphism (via Method Over-riding) java𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑮𝒖𝒆𝒔𝒕"); }}𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒆𝒙𝒕𝒆𝒏𝒅𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏"); }}𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑻𝒆𝒔𝒕 { 𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒔𝒕𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒄 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒎𝒂𝒊𝒏(𝑺𝒕𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒈[] 𝒂𝒓𝒈𝒔) { 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋 = 𝒏𝒆𝒘 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏(); // 👈 𝑹𝒆𝒇𝒆𝒓𝒆𝒏𝒄𝒆 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆: 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 | 𝑶𝒃𝒋𝒆𝒄𝒕 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆:𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋.𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆(); // 👈 𝑪𝒂𝒍𝒍𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏’𝒔 𝒎𝒆𝒕𝒉𝒐𝒅 𝒂𝒕 𝒓𝒖𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒎𝒆(𝒅𝒚𝒏𝒂𝒎𝒊𝒄 𝒃𝒊𝒏𝒅𝒊𝒏𝒈) }}

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is Exception Handling?Exception handling is a way to manage errors that occur while a program is running. Instead of stopping the entire program when an error happens, exception handling lets you control what should happen when something goes wrong.🌟 Why is it important?It helps prevent the program from crashing.It allows the program to continue running even after an error.It shows clear and friendly error messages to the user.It makes debugging and fixing issues easier.🌟 How does it work?You write the code that might cause an error inside a special block. If an error happens, another block will handle it. This keeps the program safe and avoids unexpected crashes.🌟 Key Terms:Try: The block where you write the code that might cause an error.Catch: The block where you handle the error if it occurs.Finally: A block that runs no matter what—whether there was an error or not.Throw: Used to create custom errors or exceptions.Throws: Used to declare exceptions that a method might cause.

Today's Learning Journey 📕: Stacks in JavaToday, I explored one of the fundamental data structures— the Stack.**What is a Stack?** A Stack is a linear data structure that follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle. The last element added is the first one to be removed. Think of it like a stack of plates — you add to the top and remove from the top.**Why It's Important?** Stacks are used in many areas like function calls, expression evaluation, undo features in editors, and more. Understanding how they work is essential for solving real-world problems and mastering algorithms.**Key Takeaways:** 1. Core Operations: push(), pop(), peek(), and isEmpty()2. Implementation: Explored Java's built-in Stack class and also implemented it manually using arrays and linked lists. 3. Applications: Helps build intuition for recursion, backtracking, and parsing tasks.#Java #DataStructures #Stack #CodingJourney #Programming #TechLearning

كلامنا النهاردة عن  JVM، JRE، وJDK... مين هم أبطال القصة؟في عالم جافا، عندنا 3 شخصيات رئيسية، وكل واحدة ليها دور مهم جدًا:يلا نغوص سوا في عالم JVM، JRE، وJDK ونفهم كل واحدة فيهم بتشتغل إزاي؟ 🧠 أولاً: JVM – Java Virtual Machine ده هو قلب القصة.تخيله كأنه "المترجم الذكي" اللي بياخد الـ Bytecode (ملفات .class) ويحوّله لحاجة الجهاز يفهمها وظيفته:يقرأ ملفات .class اللي بيطلّعها الـ Compilerيفسرها سطر بسطر ويحوّلها لـ Machine Codeيتعامل مع نظام التشغيل (Windows / Linux / macOS)بيشتغل على أي جهاز فيه JVM → عشان كده جافا بتشتغل في كل مكان!أنواعه: كل نظام تشغيل ليه JVM خاصة بيه. الكود بيشتغل على أي نظام بشرط يكون فيه JVM.🌱 ثانيًا: JRE – Java Runtime Environment📦 دي البيئة اللي بيعيش فيها برنامج جافا بعد ما تكتبه.بتتكوّن من:JVMJava Class Libraries (زي System.out, ArrayList, Scanner, …)وظيفتها: تشغّل برامج جافا الجاهزة، بس مش ينفع تكتبي أو ترجمي كود جديد بيها. مثال: لو عندك برنامج جاهز وعايزة تشغّليه → محتاجة JRE فقط.🔧 ثالثًا: JDK – Java Development Kitدي العُدّة الكاملة لأي مطوّر/مطوّرة جافا.بتحتوي على:✅ كل مكونات الـ JRE✅ أدوات التطوير (Dev Tools):javac: لتحويل الكود لـ Bytecodejava: لتشغيل البرامجjavadoc: لتوليد التوثيقDebuggers: لتتبع الأخطاءوظيفتها:كتابة الكودترجمتهتشغيلهاختباره يعني باختصار: لو هتشتغل على مشروع جافا → لازم تنزّل الـ JDK الـ JRE لوحده مش هيكفي.لو وصلت لحد هنا، شاركني: أنت كنت عارف الفرق بينهم قبل كده؟ ولا دي أول مرة الصورة توضح؟ 😊👇hashtag#Java hashtag#JVM hashtag#JRE hashtag#JDK hashtag#LearnJava hashtag#Backend hashtag#ProgrammingBasics hashtag#لينكدإن

Maroš Varchola is a 22 year old founder based in Slovakia that builds software that processes tens of thousands of euros a month. 💸Reconciliation is the process of matching transaction data with business processes, like outgoing invoices. In the past reconciliation has been a messy, non-deterministic process, but things are changing. ISO20022 is the "HTTP" protocol of money. As banks adopt improved data formats around financial data like ISO20022, transaction matching becomes much simpler: end to end tracking IDs make reconciliation deterministic and unambigious.Maroš contributed end to end ID support to iso20022.js and uses it in production to perfectly reconcile tens of thousands of euros of invoices a month. iso20022.js is the leading library that allows developers to interact with the modern banking system. With almost a dozen contributors, it has a bigger engineering team than most startups!

🚀 Lesson Learned: Read the Docs, Save Hours! 📚⏱️While working on my final year project — a fake profile detection system using Instagram data — I spent nearly 2-3 hours trying to integrate Apify's Instagram scraper using raw API calls, handling URLs, tokens, HTTP errors… the usual grind. 😓Everything looked right, but I was constantly getting empty or default responses. Just when the frustration started to build up, I took a step back and finally did what I should have done first — I read the official Apify documentation.And guess what? 💡Turns out, Apify provides a clean and powerful Python SDK (apify-client) that makes the whole process so much easier and more reliable. Instead of manually hitting endpoints, handling dataset IDs, and parsing results, I could just:✅ Initialize the client ✅ Call the actor with run_input ✅ Iterate over results like a breezeThis experience reminded me of something simple but powerful:“Documentation is not optional — it’s a superpower.” 💥Next time, before diving into hours of trial-and-error, I’ll definitely start by checking the docs first. It’s a small habit that saves massive time.

JavaScript + XML = The Original Data Power Duo Before REST APIs returned slick JSON responses... Before fetch() made things feel magical... There was AJAX with XML — and it was revolutionary. While today we mostly use JSON, XML once ruled the web for data exchange. But here’s what’s cool: JavaScript still works smoothly with XML when needed — especially in legacy systems, enterprise integrations, and document-heavy APIs. Why XML is still relevant:Widely used in enterprise & government systemsStrong schema & validation support (XSD)Excellent for document-based dataPlays well with JavaScript via DOMParser, XMLHttpRequest, etc.Whether you're modernizing legacy platforms or diving into complex integrations, understanding XML with JavaScript gives you a serious edge.  Are you still working with XML in your projects? Standardisation of Railway signallingThere Are in principle today 3 ways of interlocking design. 1) free wired2) object oriented3) geographicalSo what defines their adavantages and disadvantages, regading Generic and Specific applications?Engineering: nr 3) provides a high amount of Generic functionality and a little part of specific engineering. Gives the supplier more work at the start, but simplifies all over time. Rating 3-2-1 in quality. Specifying SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Testing SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Resposibilities: testing of SA is typically moved back to the infrastructure manager, where 1) gives a lot of work, while 3) is reduced to a functional level. Bane NOR have chosen 3) to get a high amount of Generic functionality and Standardised Engineering for its National ERTMS L2 system, due to the totality of deliveries. Based on our experience this is the right way to go to limit amount of work and to maximise the level of standardisation of functionality throughout the network, and limits all local variants of today.

After years of building backend systems with Spring Boot, if there’s one thing that keeps standing out—it’s that a well-designed API is more than just a contract. It’s the front door to your system, the layer everyone interacts with, and the first place things break if you’re not careful.I still remember working on an old monolithic app—huge codebase, tight coupling, and one giant controller doing everything. Refactoring that into clean, RESTful microservices was like fresh air. Suddenly, each service had its own purpose, its own voice—and scaling became a breeze.A few REST essentials I’ve come to love along the way:  @RestController – Making it easy to return clean, structured JSON without all the XML baggage. @GetMapping / @PostMapping / @PutMapping – Routes that make sense and read like documentation. @PreAuthorize – Because security isn't optional, especially when you're exposing data to the world. @FeignClient – Let your services talk like friends, not strangers.What I’ve learned is: REST APIs aren’t just about exposing data—they’re about designing systems that are secure, reliable, and future-proof. Whether it’s handling failures with proper status codes, paginating heavy data, or versioning APIs to avoid breaking consumers—it’s all part of the craft.If you’ve ever refactored an API, migrated from SOAP, or turned a legacy app into lean microservices, you know the challenges (and the satisfaction).What’s your biggest lesson or “aha!” moment with REST APIs? Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is a Package?A package is like a folder in your computer that helps you organize your Java files (classes, interfaces, etc.).🌟 Why do we use Packages?To organize code neatlyTo avoid name conflicts (two classes can have the same name if they are in different packages)To reuse code easilyTo make project structure clean and easy to manage🌟 Types of Packages:Built-in packages – already available in Java (like java.util, java.io)User-defined packages – created by us to group our own classes🌟 How to Create and Use a Package?You create a package using the package keyword.You use it by importing it with the import keyword.🌟 Think of it like this:Your computer has folders (packages)Inside folders, you have files (Java classes)You can open and use files from any folder using the correct path (importing the package)

🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠, 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 & 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 — 𝐒𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐟𝐢𝐞𝐝!If you're working with inheritance in Java or automation frameworks like Selenium, this is one of the most powerful concepts👇🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 ✅ Definition: Redefining a method of the parent class in the child class🔹 Key Rules:1. Method signature must be exactly the same2. Return type must be the same or covariant3. Access modifier can be more permissive (not more restrictive)4. Happens only in inheritance5. Enables runtime polymorphism⚡ 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 (𝐚.𝐤.𝐚 𝐋𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠) ✅ The method to execute is decided at runtime 🔹 Used when:1. You're overriding methods2. Based on object type, not the reference type📌 | 𝐉𝐚𝐯𝐚 𝐝𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐭 𝐫𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐰𝐡𝐢𝐜𝐡 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐝𝐞𝐧 𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐞𝐱𝐞𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐞 𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐨𝐛𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐭𝐲𝐩𝐞🛠️ 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 ✅ Occurs when a parent class reference is used to call an overridden method in the child class✅ Example: Run-Time Polymorphism (via Method Over-riding) java𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑮𝒖𝒆𝒔𝒕"); }}𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒆𝒙𝒕𝒆𝒏𝒅𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏"); }}𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑻𝒆𝒔𝒕 { 𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒔𝒕𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒄 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒎𝒂𝒊𝒏(𝑺𝒕𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒈[] 𝒂𝒓𝒈𝒔) { 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋 = 𝒏𝒆𝒘 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏(); // 👈 𝑹𝒆𝒇𝒆𝒓𝒆𝒏𝒄𝒆 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆: 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 | 𝑶𝒃𝒋𝒆𝒄𝒕 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆:𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋.𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆(); // 👈 𝑪𝒂𝒍𝒍𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏’𝒔 𝒎𝒆𝒕𝒉𝒐𝒅 𝒂𝒕 𝒓𝒖𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒎𝒆(𝒅𝒚𝒏𝒂𝒎𝒊𝒄 𝒃𝒊𝒏𝒅𝒊𝒏𝒈) }}

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is Exception Handling?Exception handling is a way to manage errors that occur while a program is running. Instead of stopping the entire program when an error happens, exception handling lets you control what should happen when something goes wrong.🌟 Why is it important?It helps prevent the program from crashing.It allows the program to continue running even after an error.It shows clear and friendly error messages to the user.It makes debugging and fixing issues easier.🌟 How does it work?You write the code that might cause an error inside a special block. If an error happens, another block will handle it. This keeps the program safe and avoids unexpected crashes.🌟 Key Terms:Try: The block where you write the code that might cause an error.Catch: The block where you handle the error if it occurs.Finally: A block that runs no matter what—whether there was an error or not.Throw: Used to create custom errors or exceptions.Throws: Used to declare exceptions that a method might cause.

Today's Learning Journey 📕: Stacks in JavaToday, I explored one of the fundamental data structures— the Stack.**What is a Stack?** A Stack is a linear data structure that follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle. The last element added is the first one to be removed. Think of it like a stack of plates — you add to the top and remove from the top.**Why It's Important?** Stacks are used in many areas like function calls, expression evaluation, undo features in editors, and more. Understanding how they work is essential for solving real-world problems and mastering algorithms.**Key Takeaways:** 1. Core Operations: push(), pop(), peek(), and isEmpty()2. Implementation: Explored Java's built-in Stack class and also implemented it manually using arrays and linked lists. 3. Applications: Helps build intuition for recursion, backtracking, and parsing tasks.#Java #DataStructures #Stack #CodingJourney #Programming #TechLearning

كلامنا النهاردة عن  JVM، JRE، وJDK... مين هم أبطال القصة؟في عالم جافا، عندنا 3 شخصيات رئيسية، وكل واحدة ليها دور مهم جدًا:يلا نغوص سوا في عالم JVM، JRE، وJDK ونفهم كل واحدة فيهم بتشتغل إزاي؟ 🧠 أولاً: JVM – Java Virtual Machine ده هو قلب القصة.تخيله كأنه "المترجم الذكي" اللي بياخد الـ Bytecode (ملفات .class) ويحوّله لحاجة الجهاز يفهمها وظيفته:يقرأ ملفات .class اللي بيطلّعها الـ Compilerيفسرها سطر بسطر ويحوّلها لـ Machine Codeيتعامل مع نظام التشغيل (Windows / Linux / macOS)بيشتغل على أي جهاز فيه JVM → عشان كده جافا بتشتغل في كل مكان!أنواعه: كل نظام تشغيل ليه JVM خاصة بيه. الكود بيشتغل على أي نظام بشرط يكون فيه JVM.🌱 ثانيًا: JRE – Java Runtime Environment📦 دي البيئة اللي بيعيش فيها برنامج جافا بعد ما تكتبه.بتتكوّن من:JVMJava Class Libraries (زي System.out, ArrayList, Scanner, …)وظيفتها: تشغّل برامج جافا الجاهزة، بس مش ينفع تكتبي أو ترجمي كود جديد بيها. مثال: لو عندك برنامج جاهز وعايزة تشغّليه → محتاجة JRE فقط.🔧 ثالثًا: JDK – Java Development Kitدي العُدّة الكاملة لأي مطوّر/مطوّرة جافا.بتحتوي على:✅ كل مكونات الـ JRE✅ أدوات التطوير (Dev Tools):javac: لتحويل الكود لـ Bytecodejava: لتشغيل البرامجjavadoc: لتوليد التوثيقDebuggers: لتتبع الأخطاءوظيفتها:كتابة الكودترجمتهتشغيلهاختباره يعني باختصار: لو هتشتغل على مشروع جافا → لازم تنزّل الـ JDK الـ JRE لوحده مش هيكفي.لو وصلت لحد هنا، شاركني: أنت كنت عارف الفرق بينهم قبل كده؟ ولا دي أول مرة الصورة توضح؟ 😊👇hashtag#Java hashtag#JVM hashtag#JRE hashtag#JDK hashtag#LearnJava hashtag#Backend hashtag#ProgrammingBasics hashtag#لينكدإن

Maroš Varchola is a 22 year old founder based in Slovakia that builds software that processes tens of thousands of euros a month. 💸Reconciliation is the process of matching transaction data with business processes, like outgoing invoices. In the past reconciliation has been a messy, non-deterministic process, but things are changing. ISO20022 is the "HTTP" protocol of money. As banks adopt improved data formats around financial data like ISO20022, transaction matching becomes much simpler: end to end tracking IDs make reconciliation deterministic and unambigious.Maroš contributed end to end ID support to iso20022.js and uses it in production to perfectly reconcile tens of thousands of euros of invoices a month. iso20022.js is the leading library that allows developers to interact with the modern banking system. With almost a dozen contributors, it has a bigger engineering team than most startups!

🚀 Lesson Learned: Read the Docs, Save Hours! 📚⏱️While working on my final year project — a fake profile detection system using Instagram data — I spent nearly 2-3 hours trying to integrate Apify's Instagram scraper using raw API calls, handling URLs, tokens, HTTP errors… the usual grind. 😓Everything looked right, but I was constantly getting empty or default responses. Just when the frustration started to build up, I took a step back and finally did what I should have done first — I read the official Apify documentation.And guess what? 💡Turns out, Apify provides a clean and powerful Python SDK (apify-client) that makes the whole process so much easier and more reliable. Instead of manually hitting endpoints, handling dataset IDs, and parsing results, I could just:✅ Initialize the client ✅ Call the actor with run_input ✅ Iterate over results like a breezeThis experience reminded me of something simple but powerful:“Documentation is not optional — it’s a superpower.” 💥Next time, before diving into hours of trial-and-error, I’ll definitely start by checking the docs first. It’s a small habit that saves massive time.

JavaScript + XML = The Original Data Power Duo Before REST APIs returned slick JSON responses... Before fetch() made things feel magical... There was AJAX with XML — and it was revolutionary. While today we mostly use JSON, XML once ruled the web for data exchange. But here’s what’s cool: JavaScript still works smoothly with XML when needed — especially in legacy systems, enterprise integrations, and document-heavy APIs. Why XML is still relevant:Widely used in enterprise & government systemsStrong schema & validation support (XSD)Excellent for document-based dataPlays well with JavaScript via DOMParser, XMLHttpRequest, etc.Whether you're modernizing legacy platforms or diving into complex integrations, understanding XML with JavaScript gives you a serious edge.  Are you still working with XML in your projects? Standardisation of Railway signallingThere Are in principle today 3 ways of interlocking design. 1) free wired2) object oriented3) geographicalSo what defines their adavantages and disadvantages, regading Generic and Specific applications?Engineering: nr 3) provides a high amount of Generic functionality and a little part of specific engineering. Gives the supplier more work at the start, but simplifies all over time. Rating 3-2-1 in quality. Specifying SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Testing SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Resposibilities: testing of SA is typically moved back to the infrastructure manager, where 1) gives a lot of work, while 3) is reduced to a functional level. Bane NOR have chosen 3) to get a high amount of Generic functionality and Standardised Engineering for its National ERTMS L2 system, due to the totality of deliveries. Based on our experience this is the right way to go to limit amount of work and to maximise the level of standardisation of functionality throughout the network, and limits all local variants of today.

After years of building backend systems with Spring Boot, if there’s one thing that keeps standing out—it’s that a well-designed API is more than just a contract. It’s the front door to your system, the layer everyone interacts with, and the first place things break if you’re not careful.I still remember working on an old monolithic app—huge codebase, tight coupling, and one giant controller doing everything. Refactoring that into clean, RESTful microservices was like fresh air. Suddenly, each service had its own purpose, its own voice—and scaling became a breeze.A few REST essentials I’ve come to love along the way:  @RestController – Making it easy to return clean, structured JSON without all the XML baggage. @GetMapping / @PostMapping / @PutMapping – Routes that make sense and read like documentation. @PreAuthorize – Because security isn't optional, especially when you're exposing data to the world. @FeignClient – Let your services talk like friends, not strangers.What I’ve learned is: REST APIs aren’t just about exposing data—they’re about designing systems that are secure, reliable, and future-proof. Whether it’s handling failures with proper status codes, paginating heavy data, or versioning APIs to avoid breaking consumers—it’s all part of the craft.If you’ve ever refactored an API, migrated from SOAP, or turned a legacy app into lean microservices, you know the challenges (and the satisfaction).What’s your biggest lesson or “aha!” moment with REST APIs? In Java, the final keyword is used to restrict the modification of variables, methods, and classes. There are 3 ways to input in the final keyword.. 3 ways to constext -:-->Final Variable-:A final variable cannot be reassigned after it has been initialized.For objects, final means the reference cannot change, but the object's contents can (unless the object itself is immutable).-->Final Method-:A final method cannot be overridden by subclasses.-->Final Class-:A final class cannot be extended (no subclassing).hashtag#Java hashtag#Coding hashtag#Learning hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Programming hashtag#TechJourney

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is a Package?A package is like a folder in your computer that helps you organize your Java files (classes, interfaces, etc.).🌟 Why do we use Packages?To organize code neatlyTo avoid name conflicts (two classes can have the same name if they are in different packages)To reuse code easilyTo make project structure clean and easy to manage🌟 Types of Packages:Built-in packages – already available in Java (like java.util, java.io)User-defined packages – created by us to group our own classes🌟 How to Create and Use a Package?You create a package using the package keyword.You use it by importing it with the import keyword.🌟 Think of it like this:Your computer has folders (packages)Inside folders, you have files (Java classes)You can open and use files from any folder using the correct path (importing the package)

🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠, 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 & 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 — 𝐒𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐟𝐢𝐞𝐝!If you're working with inheritance in Java or automation frameworks like Selenium, this is one of the most powerful concepts👇🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 ✅ Definition: Redefining a method of the parent class in the child class🔹 Key Rules:1. Method signature must be exactly the same2. Return type must be the same or covariant3. Access modifier can be more permissive (not more restrictive)4. Happens only in inheritance5. Enables runtime polymorphism⚡ 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 (𝐚.𝐤.𝐚 𝐋𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠) ✅ The method to execute is decided at runtime 🔹 Used when:1. You're overriding methods2. Based on object type, not the reference type📌 | 𝐉𝐚𝐯𝐚 𝐝𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐭 𝐫𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐰𝐡𝐢𝐜𝐡 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐝𝐞𝐧 𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐞𝐱𝐞𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐞 𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐨𝐛𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐭𝐲𝐩𝐞🛠️ 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 ✅ Occurs when a parent class reference is used to call an overridden method in the child class✅ Example: Run-Time Polymorphism (via Method Over-riding) java𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑮𝒖𝒆𝒔𝒕"); }}𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒆𝒙𝒕𝒆𝒏𝒅𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏"); }}𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑻𝒆𝒔𝒕 { 𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒔𝒕𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒄 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒎𝒂𝒊𝒏(𝑺𝒕𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒈[] 𝒂𝒓𝒈𝒔) { 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋 = 𝒏𝒆𝒘 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏(); // 👈 𝑹𝒆𝒇𝒆𝒓𝒆𝒏𝒄𝒆 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆: 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 | 𝑶𝒃𝒋𝒆𝒄𝒕 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆:𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋.𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆(); // 👈 𝑪𝒂𝒍𝒍𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏’𝒔 𝒎𝒆𝒕𝒉𝒐𝒅 𝒂𝒕 𝒓𝒖𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒎𝒆(𝒅𝒚𝒏𝒂𝒎𝒊𝒄 𝒃𝒊𝒏𝒅𝒊𝒏𝒈) }}

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is Exception Handling?Exception handling is a way to manage errors that occur while a program is running. Instead of stopping the entire program when an error happens, exception handling lets you control what should happen when something goes wrong.🌟 Why is it important?It helps prevent the program from crashing.It allows the program to continue running even after an error.It shows clear and friendly error messages to the user.It makes debugging and fixing issues easier.🌟 How does it work?You write the code that might cause an error inside a special block. If an error happens, another block will handle it. This keeps the program safe and avoids unexpected crashes.🌟 Key Terms:Try: The block where you write the code that might cause an error.Catch: The block where you handle the error if it occurs.Finally: A block that runs no matter what—whether there was an error or not.Throw: Used to create custom errors or exceptions.Throws: Used to declare exceptions that a method might cause.

Today's Learning Journey 📕: Stacks in JavaToday, I explored one of the fundamental data structures— the Stack.**What is a Stack?** A Stack is a linear data structure that follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle. The last element added is the first one to be removed. Think of it like a stack of plates — you add to the top and remove from the top.**Why It's Important?** Stacks are used in many areas like function calls, expression evaluation, undo features in editors, and more. Understanding how they work is essential for solving real-world problems and mastering algorithms.**Key Takeaways:** 1. Core Operations: push(), pop(), peek(), and isEmpty()2. Implementation: Explored Java's built-in Stack class and also implemented it manually using arrays and linked lists. 3. Applications: Helps build intuition for recursion, backtracking, and parsing tasks.#Java #DataStructures #Stack #CodingJourney #Programming #TechLearning

كلامنا النهاردة عن  JVM، JRE، وJDK... مين هم أبطال القصة؟في عالم جافا، عندنا 3 شخصيات رئيسية، وكل واحدة ليها دور مهم جدًا:يلا نغوص سوا في عالم JVM، JRE، وJDK ونفهم كل واحدة فيهم بتشتغل إزاي؟ 🧠 أولاً: JVM – Java Virtual Machine ده هو قلب القصة.تخيله كأنه "المترجم الذكي" اللي بياخد الـ Bytecode (ملفات .class) ويحوّله لحاجة الجهاز يفهمها وظيفته:يقرأ ملفات .class اللي بيطلّعها الـ Compilerيفسرها سطر بسطر ويحوّلها لـ Machine Codeيتعامل مع نظام التشغيل (Windows / Linux / macOS)بيشتغل على أي جهاز فيه JVM → عشان كده جافا بتشتغل في كل مكان!أنواعه: كل نظام تشغيل ليه JVM خاصة بيه. الكود بيشتغل على أي نظام بشرط يكون فيه JVM.🌱 ثانيًا: JRE – Java Runtime Environment📦 دي البيئة اللي بيعيش فيها برنامج جافا بعد ما تكتبه.بتتكوّن من:JVMJava Class Libraries (زي System.out, ArrayList, Scanner, …)وظيفتها: تشغّل برامج جافا الجاهزة، بس مش ينفع تكتبي أو ترجمي كود جديد بيها. مثال: لو عندك برنامج جاهز وعايزة تشغّليه → محتاجة JRE فقط.🔧 ثالثًا: JDK – Java Development Kitدي العُدّة الكاملة لأي مطوّر/مطوّرة جافا.بتحتوي على:✅ كل مكونات الـ JRE✅ أدوات التطوير (Dev Tools):javac: لتحويل الكود لـ Bytecodejava: لتشغيل البرامجjavadoc: لتوليد التوثيقDebuggers: لتتبع الأخطاءوظيفتها:كتابة الكودترجمتهتشغيلهاختباره يعني باختصار: لو هتشتغل على مشروع جافا → لازم تنزّل الـ JDK الـ JRE لوحده مش هيكفي.لو وصلت لحد هنا، شاركني: أنت كنت عارف الفرق بينهم قبل كده؟ ولا دي أول مرة الصورة توضح؟ 😊👇hashtag#Java hashtag#JVM hashtag#JRE hashtag#JDK hashtag#LearnJava hashtag#Backend hashtag#ProgrammingBasics hashtag#لينكدإن

Maroš Varchola is a 22 year old founder based in Slovakia that builds software that processes tens of thousands of euros a month. 💸Reconciliation is the process of matching transaction data with business processes, like outgoing invoices. In the past reconciliation has been a messy, non-deterministic process, but things are changing. ISO20022 is the "HTTP" protocol of money. As banks adopt improved data formats around financial data like ISO20022, transaction matching becomes much simpler: end to end tracking IDs make reconciliation deterministic and unambigious.Maroš contributed end to end ID support to iso20022.js and uses it in production to perfectly reconcile tens of thousands of euros of invoices a month. iso20022.js is the leading library that allows developers to interact with the modern banking system. With almost a dozen contributors, it has a bigger engineering team than most startups!

🚀 Lesson Learned: Read the Docs, Save Hours! 📚⏱️While working on my final year project — a fake profile detection system using Instagram data — I spent nearly 2-3 hours trying to integrate Apify's Instagram scraper using raw API calls, handling URLs, tokens, HTTP errors… the usual grind. 😓Everything looked right, but I was constantly getting empty or default responses. Just when the frustration started to build up, I took a step back and finally did what I should have done first — I read the official Apify documentation.And guess what? 💡Turns out, Apify provides a clean and powerful Python SDK (apify-client) that makes the whole process so much easier and more reliable. Instead of manually hitting endpoints, handling dataset IDs, and parsing results, I could just:✅ Initialize the client ✅ Call the actor with run_input ✅ Iterate over results like a breezeThis experience reminded me of something simple but powerful:“Documentation is not optional — it’s a superpower.” 💥Next time, before diving into hours of trial-and-error, I’ll definitely start by checking the docs first. It’s a small habit that saves massive time.

JavaScript + XML = The Original Data Power Duo Before REST APIs returned slick JSON responses... Before fetch() made things feel magical... There was AJAX with XML — and it was revolutionary. While today we mostly use JSON, XML once ruled the web for data exchange. But here’s what’s cool: JavaScript still works smoothly with XML when needed — especially in legacy systems, enterprise integrations, and document-heavy APIs. Why XML is still relevant:Widely used in enterprise & government systemsStrong schema & validation support (XSD)Excellent for document-based dataPlays well with JavaScript via DOMParser, XMLHttpRequest, etc.Whether you're modernizing legacy platforms or diving into complex integrations, understanding XML with JavaScript gives you a serious edge.  Are you still working with XML in your projects? Standardisation of Railway signallingThere Are in principle today 3 ways of interlocking design. 1) free wired2) object oriented3) geographicalSo what defines their adavantages and disadvantages, regading Generic and Specific applications?Engineering: nr 3) provides a high amount of Generic functionality and a little part of specific engineering. Gives the supplier more work at the start, but simplifies all over time. Rating 3-2-1 in quality. Specifying SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Testing SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Resposibilities: testing of SA is typically moved back to the infrastructure manager, where 1) gives a lot of work, while 3) is reduced to a functional level. Bane NOR have chosen 3) to get a high amount of Generic functionality and Standardised Engineering for its National ERTMS L2 system, due to the totality of deliveries. Based on our experience this is the right way to go to limit amount of work and to maximise the level of standardisation of functionality throughout the network, and limits all local variants of today.

After years of building backend systems with Spring Boot, if there’s one thing that keeps standing out—it’s that a well-designed API is more than just a contract. It’s the front door to your system, the layer everyone interacts with, and the first place things break if you’re not careful.I still remember working on an old monolithic app—huge codebase, tight coupling, and one giant controller doing everything. Refactoring that into clean, RESTful microservices was like fresh air. Suddenly, each service had its own purpose, its own voice—and scaling became a breeze.A few REST essentials I’ve come to love along the way:  @RestController – Making it easy to return clean, structured JSON without all the XML baggage. @GetMapping / @PostMapping / @PutMapping – Routes that make sense and read like documentation. @PreAuthorize – Because security isn't optional, especially when you're exposing data to the world. @FeignClient – Let your services talk like friends, not strangers.What I’ve learned is: REST APIs aren’t just about exposing data—they’re about designing systems that are secure, reliable, and future-proof. Whether it’s handling failures with proper status codes, paginating heavy data, or versioning APIs to avoid breaking consumers—it’s all part of the craft.If you’ve ever refactored an API, migrated from SOAP, or turned a legacy app into lean microservices, you know the challenges (and the satisfaction).What’s your biggest lesson or “aha!” moment with REST APIs? Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is a Package?A package is like a folder in your computer that helps you organize your Java files (classes, interfaces, etc.).🌟 Why do we use Packages?To organize code neatlyTo avoid name conflicts (two classes can have the same name if they are in different packages)To reuse code easilyTo make project structure clean and easy to manage🌟 Types of Packages:Built-in packages – already available in Java (like java.util, java.io)User-defined packages – created by us to group our own classes🌟 How to Create and Use a Package?You create a package using the package keyword.You use it by importing it with the import keyword.🌟 Think of it like this:Your computer has folders (packages)Inside folders, you have files (Java classes)You can open and use files from any folder using the correct path (importing the package)

🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠, 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 & 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 — 𝐒𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐟𝐢𝐞𝐝!If you're working with inheritance in Java or automation frameworks like Selenium, this is one of the most powerful concepts👇🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 ✅ Definition: Redefining a method of the parent class in the child class🔹 Key Rules:1. Method signature must be exactly the same2. Return type must be the same or covariant3. Access modifier can be more permissive (not more restrictive)4. Happens only in inheritance5. Enables runtime polymorphism⚡ 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 (𝐚.𝐤.𝐚 𝐋𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠) ✅ The method to execute is decided at runtime 🔹 Used when:1. You're overriding methods2. Based on object type, not the reference type📌 | 𝐉𝐚𝐯𝐚 𝐝𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐭 𝐫𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐰𝐡𝐢𝐜𝐡 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐝𝐞𝐧 𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐞𝐱𝐞𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐞 𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐨𝐛𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐭𝐲𝐩𝐞🛠️ 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 ✅ Occurs when a parent class reference is used to call an overridden method in the child class✅ Example: Run-Time Polymorphism (via Method Over-riding) java𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑮𝒖𝒆𝒔𝒕"); }}𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒆𝒙𝒕𝒆𝒏𝒅𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏"); }}𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑻𝒆𝒔𝒕 { 𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒔𝒕𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒄 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒎𝒂𝒊𝒏(𝑺𝒕𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒈[] 𝒂𝒓𝒈𝒔) { 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋 = 𝒏𝒆𝒘 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏(); // 👈 𝑹𝒆𝒇𝒆𝒓𝒆𝒏𝒄𝒆 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆: 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 | 𝑶𝒃𝒋𝒆𝒄𝒕 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆:𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋.𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆(); // 👈 𝑪𝒂𝒍𝒍𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏’𝒔 𝒎𝒆𝒕𝒉𝒐𝒅 𝒂𝒕 𝒓𝒖𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒎𝒆(𝒅𝒚𝒏𝒂𝒎𝒊𝒄 𝒃𝒊𝒏𝒅𝒊𝒏𝒈) }}

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is Exception Handling?Exception handling is a way to manage errors that occur while a program is running. Instead of stopping the entire program when an error happens, exception handling lets you control what should happen when something goes wrong.🌟 Why is it important?It helps prevent the program from crashing.It allows the program to continue running even after an error.It shows clear and friendly error messages to the user.It makes debugging and fixing issues easier.🌟 How does it work?You write the code that might cause an error inside a special block. If an error happens, another block will handle it. This keeps the program safe and avoids unexpected crashes.🌟 Key Terms:Try: The block where you write the code that might cause an error.Catch: The block where you handle the error if it occurs.Finally: A block that runs no matter what—whether there was an error or not.Throw: Used to create custom errors or exceptions.Throws: Used to declare exceptions that a method might cause.

Today's Learning Journey 📕: Stacks in JavaToday, I explored one of the fundamental data structures— the Stack.**What is a Stack?** A Stack is a linear data structure that follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle. The last element added is the first one to be removed. Think of it like a stack of plates — you add to the top and remove from the top.**Why It's Important?** Stacks are used in many areas like function calls, expression evaluation, undo features in editors, and more. Understanding how they work is essential for solving real-world problems and mastering algorithms.**Key Takeaways:** 1. Core Operations: push(), pop(), peek(), and isEmpty()2. Implementation: Explored Java's built-in Stack class and also implemented it manually using arrays and linked lists. 3. Applications: Helps build intuition for recursion, backtracking, and parsing tasks.#Java #DataStructures #Stack #CodingJourney #Programming #TechLearning

كلامنا النهاردة عن  JVM، JRE، وJDK... مين هم أبطال القصة؟في عالم جافا، عندنا 3 شخصيات رئيسية، وكل واحدة ليها دور مهم جدًا:يلا نغوص سوا في عالم JVM، JRE، وJDK ونفهم كل واحدة فيهم بتشتغل إزاي؟ 🧠 أولاً: JVM – Java Virtual Machine ده هو قلب القصة.تخيله كأنه "المترجم الذكي" اللي بياخد الـ Bytecode (ملفات .class) ويحوّله لحاجة الجهاز يفهمها وظيفته:يقرأ ملفات .class اللي بيطلّعها الـ Compilerيفسرها سطر بسطر ويحوّلها لـ Machine Codeيتعامل مع نظام التشغيل (Windows / Linux / macOS)بيشتغل على أي جهاز فيه JVM → عشان كده جافا بتشتغل في كل مكان!أنواعه: كل نظام تشغيل ليه JVM خاصة بيه. الكود بيشتغل على أي نظام بشرط يكون فيه JVM.🌱 ثانيًا: JRE – Java Runtime Environment📦 دي البيئة اللي بيعيش فيها برنامج جافا بعد ما تكتبه.بتتكوّن من:JVMJava Class Libraries (زي System.out, ArrayList, Scanner, …)وظيفتها: تشغّل برامج جافا الجاهزة، بس مش ينفع تكتبي أو ترجمي كود جديد بيها. مثال: لو عندك برنامج جاهز وعايزة تشغّليه → محتاجة JRE فقط.🔧 ثالثًا: JDK – Java Development Kitدي العُدّة الكاملة لأي مطوّر/مطوّرة جافا.بتحتوي على:✅ كل مكونات الـ JRE✅ أدوات التطوير (Dev Tools):javac: لتحويل الكود لـ Bytecodejava: لتشغيل البرامجjavadoc: لتوليد التوثيقDebuggers: لتتبع الأخطاءوظيفتها:كتابة الكودترجمتهتشغيلهاختباره يعني باختصار: لو هتشتغل على مشروع جافا → لازم تنزّل الـ JDK الـ JRE لوحده مش هيكفي.لو وصلت لحد هنا، شاركني: أنت كنت عارف الفرق بينهم قبل كده؟ ولا دي أول مرة الصورة توضح؟ 😊👇hashtag#Java hashtag#JVM hashtag#JRE hashtag#JDK hashtag#LearnJava hashtag#Backend hashtag#ProgrammingBasics hashtag#لينكدإن

Maroš Varchola is a 22 year old founder based in Slovakia that builds software that processes tens of thousands of euros a month. 💸Reconciliation is the process of matching transaction data with business processes, like outgoing invoices. In the past reconciliation has been a messy, non-deterministic process, but things are changing. ISO20022 is the "HTTP" protocol of money. As banks adopt improved data formats around financial data like ISO20022, transaction matching becomes much simpler: end to end tracking IDs make reconciliation deterministic and unambigious.Maroš contributed end to end ID support to iso20022.js and uses it in production to perfectly reconcile tens of thousands of euros of invoices a month. iso20022.js is the leading library that allows developers to interact with the modern banking system. With almost a dozen contributors, it has a bigger engineering team than most startups!

🚀 Lesson Learned: Read the Docs, Save Hours! 📚⏱️While working on my final year project — a fake profile detection system using Instagram data — I spent nearly 2-3 hours trying to integrate Apify's Instagram scraper using raw API calls, handling URLs, tokens, HTTP errors… the usual grind. 😓Everything looked right, but I was constantly getting empty or default responses. Just when the frustration started to build up, I took a step back and finally did what I should have done first — I read the official Apify documentation.And guess what? 💡Turns out, Apify provides a clean and powerful Python SDK (apify-client) that makes the whole process so much easier and more reliable. Instead of manually hitting endpoints, handling dataset IDs, and parsing results, I could just:✅ Initialize the client ✅ Call the actor with run_input ✅ Iterate over results like a breezeThis experience reminded me of something simple but powerful:“Documentation is not optional — it’s a superpower.” 💥Next time, before diving into hours of trial-and-error, I’ll definitely start by checking the docs first. It’s a small habit that saves massive time.

JavaScript + XML = The Original Data Power Duo Before REST APIs returned slick JSON responses... Before fetch() made things feel magical... There was AJAX with XML — and it was revolutionary. While today we mostly use JSON, XML once ruled the web for data exchange. But here’s what’s cool: JavaScript still works smoothly with XML when needed — especially in legacy systems, enterprise integrations, and document-heavy APIs. Why XML is still relevant:Widely used in enterprise & government systemsStrong schema & validation support (XSD)Excellent for document-based dataPlays well with JavaScript via DOMParser, XMLHttpRequest, etc.Whether you're modernizing legacy platforms or diving into complex integrations, understanding XML with JavaScript gives you a serious edge.  Are you still working with XML in your projects? Standardisation of Railway signallingThere Are in principle today 3 ways of interlocking design. 1) free wired2) object oriented3) geographicalSo what defines their adavantages and disadvantages, regading Generic and Specific applications?Engineering: nr 3) provides a high amount of Generic functionality and a little part of specific engineering. Gives the supplier more work at the start, but simplifies all over time. Rating 3-2-1 in quality. Specifying SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Testing SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Resposibilities: testing of SA is typically moved back to the infrastructure manager, where 1) gives a lot of work, while 3) is reduced to a functional level. Bane NOR have chosen 3) to get a high amount of Generic functionality and Standardised Engineering for its National ERTMS L2 system, due to the totality of deliveries. Based on our experience this is the right way to go to limit amount of work and to maximise the level of standardisation of functionality throughout the network, and limits all local variants of today.

Engineering Industries eXcellence is supporting the hashtag#digitalization of critical port machinery for one of South America's largest logistics operators. ⚙️🚢 This industry leader, responsible for 18% of Brazil’s cargo and container traffic, needed a scalable, cloud-based solution to unlock real-time data from their ship-to-shore cranes. 🏗️After first collecting data from cranes via Siemens Industrial Edge devices, the solution processes that data into Key Performance Indicators and sends them to the Google Cloud Platform. These insights are accessible through a cloud-based business intelligence dashboard which enables stakeholders to monitor machine performance and make data-driven decisions. Our secure, scalable architecture enables real-time monitoring, fewer unplanned downtimes and smarter energy use — all aligned with the customer’s hashtag#sustainability and hashtag#Industry40 goals. Following a successful pilot deployment, the customer is now scaling the solution across their operations in South America. 🌎🦾Learn more: https://lnkd.in/gNiFaMYXEngineering Group Engineering Brasil Google Cloud Partners Google Cloud Siemens Digital Industries Software Lucas Santos Gonçalves Fabien Duboeuf Ettore Soldi Fabio Sala Sandro Buso Nishant Gupta

After years of building backend systems with Spring Boot, if there’s one thing that keeps standing out—it’s that a well-designed API is more than just a contract. It’s the front door to your system, the layer everyone interacts with, and the first place things break if you’re not careful.I still remember working on an old monolithic app—huge codebase, tight coupling, and one giant controller doing everything. Refactoring that into clean, RESTful microservices was like fresh air. Suddenly, each service had its own purpose, its own voice—and scaling became a breeze.A few REST essentials I’ve come to love along the way:  @RestController – Making it easy to return clean, structured JSON without all the XML baggage. @GetMapping / @PostMapping / @PutMapping – Routes that make sense and read like documentation. @PreAuthorize – Because security isn't optional, especially when you're exposing data to the world. @FeignClient – Let your services talk like friends, not strangers.What I’ve learned is: REST APIs aren’t just about exposing data—they’re about designing systems that are secure, reliable, and future-proof. Whether it’s handling failures with proper status codes, paginating heavy data, or versioning APIs to avoid breaking consumers—it’s all part of the craft.If you’ve ever refactored an API, migrated from SOAP, or turned a legacy app into lean microservices, you know the challenges (and the satisfaction).What’s your biggest lesson or “aha!” moment with REST APIs? In Java, the final keyword is used to restrict the modification of variables, methods, and classes. There are 3 ways to input in the final keyword.. 3 ways to constext -:-->Final Variable-:A final variable cannot be reassigned after it has been initialized.For objects, final means the reference cannot change, but the object's contents can (unless the object itself is immutable).-->Final Method-:A final method cannot be overridden by subclasses.-->Final Class-:A final class cannot be extended (no subclassing).hashtag#Java hashtag#Coding hashtag#Learning hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Programming hashtag#TechJourney

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is a Package?A package is like a folder in your computer that helps you organize your Java files (classes, interfaces, etc.).🌟 Why do we use Packages?To organize code neatlyTo avoid name conflicts (two classes can have the same name if they are in different packages)To reuse code easilyTo make project structure clean and easy to manage🌟 Types of Packages:Built-in packages – already available in Java (like java.util, java.io)User-defined packages – created by us to group our own classes🌟 How to Create and Use a Package?You create a package using the package keyword.You use it by importing it with the import keyword.🌟 Think of it like this:Your computer has folders (packages)Inside folders, you have files (Java classes)You can open and use files from any folder using the correct path (importing the package)

🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠, 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 & 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 — 𝐒𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐟𝐢𝐞𝐝!If you're working with inheritance in Java or automation frameworks like Selenium, this is one of the most powerful concepts👇🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 ✅ Definition: Redefining a method of the parent class in the child class🔹 Key Rules:1. Method signature must be exactly the same2. Return type must be the same or covariant3. Access modifier can be more permissive (not more restrictive)4. Happens only in inheritance5. Enables runtime polymorphism⚡ 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 (𝐚.𝐤.𝐚 𝐋𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠) ✅ The method to execute is decided at runtime 🔹 Used when:1. You're overriding methods2. Based on object type, not the reference type📌 | 𝐉𝐚𝐯𝐚 𝐝𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐭 𝐫𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐰𝐡𝐢𝐜𝐡 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐝𝐞𝐧 𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐞𝐱𝐞𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐞 𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐨𝐛𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐭𝐲𝐩𝐞🛠️ 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 ✅ Occurs when a parent class reference is used to call an overridden method in the child class✅ Example: Run-Time Polymorphism (via Method Over-riding) java𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑮𝒖𝒆𝒔𝒕"); }}𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒆𝒙𝒕𝒆𝒏𝒅𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏"); }}𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑻𝒆𝒔𝒕 { 𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒔𝒕𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒄 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒎𝒂𝒊𝒏(𝑺𝒕𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒈[] 𝒂𝒓𝒈𝒔) { 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋 = 𝒏𝒆𝒘 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏(); // 👈 𝑹𝒆𝒇𝒆𝒓𝒆𝒏𝒄𝒆 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆: 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 | 𝑶𝒃𝒋𝒆𝒄𝒕 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆:𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋.𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆(); // 👈 𝑪𝒂𝒍𝒍𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏’𝒔 𝒎𝒆𝒕𝒉𝒐𝒅 𝒂𝒕 𝒓𝒖𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒎𝒆(𝒅𝒚𝒏𝒂𝒎𝒊𝒄 𝒃𝒊𝒏𝒅𝒊𝒏𝒈) }}

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is Exception Handling?Exception handling is a way to manage errors that occur while a program is running. Instead of stopping the entire program when an error happens, exception handling lets you control what should happen when something goes wrong.🌟 Why is it important?It helps prevent the program from crashing.It allows the program to continue running even after an error.It shows clear and friendly error messages to the user.It makes debugging and fixing issues easier.🌟 How does it work?You write the code that might cause an error inside a special block. If an error happens, another block will handle it. This keeps the program safe and avoids unexpected crashes.🌟 Key Terms:Try: The block where you write the code that might cause an error.Catch: The block where you handle the error if it occurs.Finally: A block that runs no matter what—whether there was an error or not.Throw: Used to create custom errors or exceptions.Throws: Used to declare exceptions that a method might cause.

Today's Learning Journey 📕: Stacks in JavaToday, I explored one of the fundamental data structures— the Stack.**What is a Stack?** A Stack is a linear data structure that follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle. The last element added is the first one to be removed. Think of it like a stack of plates — you add to the top and remove from the top.**Why It's Important?** Stacks are used in many areas like function calls, expression evaluation, undo features in editors, and more. Understanding how they work is essential for solving real-world problems and mastering algorithms.**Key Takeaways:** 1. Core Operations: push(), pop(), peek(), and isEmpty()2. Implementation: Explored Java's built-in Stack class and also implemented it manually using arrays and linked lists. 3. Applications: Helps build intuition for recursion, backtracking, and parsing tasks.#Java #DataStructures #Stack #CodingJourney #Programming #TechLearning

كلامنا النهاردة عن  JVM، JRE، وJDK... مين هم أبطال القصة؟في عالم جافا، عندنا 3 شخصيات رئيسية، وكل واحدة ليها دور مهم جدًا:يلا نغوص سوا في عالم JVM، JRE، وJDK ونفهم كل واحدة فيهم بتشتغل إزاي؟ 🧠 أولاً: JVM – Java Virtual Machine ده هو قلب القصة.تخيله كأنه "المترجم الذكي" اللي بياخد الـ Bytecode (ملفات .class) ويحوّله لحاجة الجهاز يفهمها وظيفته:يقرأ ملفات .class اللي بيطلّعها الـ Compilerيفسرها سطر بسطر ويحوّلها لـ Machine Codeيتعامل مع نظام التشغيل (Windows / Linux / macOS)بيشتغل على أي جهاز فيه JVM → عشان كده جافا بتشتغل في كل مكان!أنواعه: كل نظام تشغيل ليه JVM خاصة بيه. الكود بيشتغل على أي نظام بشرط يكون فيه JVM.🌱 ثانيًا: JRE – Java Runtime Environment📦 دي البيئة اللي بيعيش فيها برنامج جافا بعد ما تكتبه.بتتكوّن من:JVMJava Class Libraries (زي System.out, ArrayList, Scanner, …)وظيفتها: تشغّل برامج جافا الجاهزة، بس مش ينفع تكتبي أو ترجمي كود جديد بيها. مثال: لو عندك برنامج جاهز وعايزة تشغّليه → محتاجة JRE فقط.🔧 ثالثًا: JDK – Java Development Kitدي العُدّة الكاملة لأي مطوّر/مطوّرة جافا.بتحتوي على:✅ كل مكونات الـ JRE✅ أدوات التطوير (Dev Tools):javac: لتحويل الكود لـ Bytecodejava: لتشغيل البرامجjavadoc: لتوليد التوثيقDebuggers: لتتبع الأخطاءوظيفتها:كتابة الكودترجمتهتشغيلهاختباره يعني باختصار: لو هتشتغل على مشروع جافا → لازم تنزّل الـ JDK الـ JRE لوحده مش هيكفي.لو وصلت لحد هنا، شاركني: أنت كنت عارف الفرق بينهم قبل كده؟ ولا دي أول مرة الصورة توضح؟ 😊👇hashtag#Java hashtag#JVM hashtag#JRE hashtag#JDK hashtag#LearnJava hashtag#Backend hashtag#ProgrammingBasics hashtag#لينكدإن

Maroš Varchola is a 22 year old founder based in Slovakia that builds software that processes tens of thousands of euros a month. 💸Reconciliation is the process of matching transaction data with business processes, like outgoing invoices. In the past reconciliation has been a messy, non-deterministic process, but things are changing. ISO20022 is the "HTTP" protocol of money. As banks adopt improved data formats around financial data like ISO20022, transaction matching becomes much simpler: end to end tracking IDs make reconciliation deterministic and unambigious.Maroš contributed end to end ID support to iso20022.js and uses it in production to perfectly reconcile tens of thousands of euros of invoices a month. iso20022.js is the leading library that allows developers to interact with the modern banking system. With almost a dozen contributors, it has a bigger engineering team than most startups!

🚀 Lesson Learned: Read the Docs, Save Hours! 📚⏱️While working on my final year project — a fake profile detection system using Instagram data — I spent nearly 2-3 hours trying to integrate Apify's Instagram scraper using raw API calls, handling URLs, tokens, HTTP errors… the usual grind. 😓Everything looked right, but I was constantly getting empty or default responses. Just when the frustration started to build up, I took a step back and finally did what I should have done first — I read the official Apify documentation.And guess what? 💡Turns out, Apify provides a clean and powerful Python SDK (apify-client) that makes the whole process so much easier and more reliable. Instead of manually hitting endpoints, handling dataset IDs, and parsing results, I could just:✅ Initialize the client ✅ Call the actor with run_input ✅ Iterate over results like a breezeThis experience reminded me of something simple but powerful:“Documentation is not optional — it’s a superpower.” 💥Next time, before diving into hours of trial-and-error, I’ll definitely start by checking the docs first. It’s a small habit that saves massive time.

JavaScript + XML = The Original Data Power Duo Before REST APIs returned slick JSON responses... Before fetch() made things feel magical... There was AJAX with XML — and it was revolutionary. While today we mostly use JSON, XML once ruled the web for data exchange. But here’s what’s cool: JavaScript still works smoothly with XML when needed — especially in legacy systems, enterprise integrations, and document-heavy APIs. Why XML is still relevant:Widely used in enterprise & government systemsStrong schema & validation support (XSD)Excellent for document-based dataPlays well with JavaScript via DOMParser, XMLHttpRequest, etc.Whether you're modernizing legacy platforms or diving into complex integrations, understanding XML with JavaScript gives you a serious edge.  Are you still working with XML in your projects? Standardisation of Railway signallingThere Are in principle today 3 ways of interlocking design. 1) free wired2) object oriented3) geographicalSo what defines their adavantages and disadvantages, regading Generic and Specific applications?Engineering: nr 3) provides a high amount of Generic functionality and a little part of specific engineering. Gives the supplier more work at the start, but simplifies all over time. Rating 3-2-1 in quality. Specifying SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Testing SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Resposibilities: testing of SA is typically moved back to the infrastructure manager, where 1) gives a lot of work, while 3) is reduced to a functional level. Bane NOR have chosen 3) to get a high amount of Generic functionality and Standardised Engineering for its National ERTMS L2 system, due to the totality of deliveries. Based on our experience this is the right way to go to limit amount of work and to maximise the level of standardisation of functionality throughout the network, and limits all local variants of today.

Engineering Industries eXcellence is supporting the hashtag#digitalization of critical port machinery for one of South America's largest logistics operators. ⚙️🚢 This industry leader, responsible for 18% of Brazil’s cargo and container traffic, needed a scalable, cloud-based solution to unlock real-time data from their ship-to-shore cranes. 🏗️After first collecting data from cranes via Siemens Industrial Edge devices, the solution processes that data into Key Performance Indicators and sends them to the Google Cloud Platform. These insights are accessible through a cloud-based business intelligence dashboard which enables stakeholders to monitor machine performance and make data-driven decisions. Our secure, scalable architecture enables real-time monitoring, fewer unplanned downtimes and smarter energy use — all aligned with the customer’s hashtag#sustainability and hashtag#Industry40 goals. Following a successful pilot deployment, the customer is now scaling the solution across their operations in South America. 🌎🦾Learn more: https://lnkd.in/gNiFaMYXEngineering Group Engineering Brasil Google Cloud Partners Google Cloud Siemens Digital Industries Software Lucas Santos Gonçalves Fabien Duboeuf Ettore Soldi Fabio Sala Sandro Buso Nishant Gupta

After years of building backend systems with Spring Boot, if there’s one thing that keeps standing out—it’s that a well-designed API is more than just a contract. It’s the front door to your system, the layer everyone interacts with, and the first place things break if you’re not careful.I still remember working on an old monolithic app—huge codebase, tight coupling, and one giant controller doing everything. Refactoring that into clean, RESTful microservices was like fresh air. Suddenly, each service had its own purpose, its own voice—and scaling became a breeze.A few REST essentials I’ve come to love along the way:  @RestController – Making it easy to return clean, structured JSON without all the XML baggage. @GetMapping / @PostMapping / @PutMapping – Routes that make sense and read like documentation. @PreAuthorize – Because security isn't optional, especially when you're exposing data to the world. @FeignClient – Let your services talk like friends, not strangers.What I’ve learned is: REST APIs aren’t just about exposing data—they’re about designing systems that are secure, reliable, and future-proof. Whether it’s handling failures with proper status codes, paginating heavy data, or versioning APIs to avoid breaking consumers—it’s all part of the craft.If you’ve ever refactored an API, migrated from SOAP, or turned a legacy app into lean microservices, you know the challenges (and the satisfaction).What’s your biggest lesson or “aha!” moment with REST APIs? 🚀 My Java Journey: From Basics to Building Real-World Applications ☕✨✨✨Day 40🌄🌄Using of Final Keyword.... In Java, the final keyword is used to restrict the modification of variables, methods, and classes. Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is a Package?A package is like a folder in your computer that helps you organize your Java files (classes, interfaces, etc.).🌟 Why do we use Packages?To organize code neatlyTo avoid name conflicts (two classes can have the same name if they are in different packages)To reuse code easilyTo make project structure clean and easy to manage🌟 Types of Packages:Built-in packages – already available in Java (like java.util, java.io)User-defined packages – created by us to group our own classes🌟 How to Create and Use a Package?You create a package using the package keyword.You use it by importing it with the import keyword.🌟 Think of it like this:Your computer has folders (packages)Inside folders, you have files (Java classes)You can open and use files from any folder using the correct path (importing the package)

🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠, 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 & 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 — 𝐒𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐟𝐢𝐞𝐝!If you're working with inheritance in Java or automation frameworks like Selenium, this is one of the most powerful concepts👇🔁 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 ✅ Definition: Redefining a method of the parent class in the child class🔹 Key Rules:1. Method signature must be exactly the same2. Return type must be the same or covariant3. Access modifier can be more permissive (not more restrictive)4. Happens only in inheritance5. Enables runtime polymorphism⚡ 𝐃𝐲𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 (𝐚.𝐤.𝐚 𝐋𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐁𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠) ✅ The method to execute is decided at runtime 🔹 Used when:1. You're overriding methods2. Based on object type, not the reference type📌 | 𝐉𝐚𝐯𝐚 𝐝𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐭 𝐫𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐰𝐡𝐢𝐜𝐡 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐝𝐞𝐧 𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐞𝐱𝐞𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐞 𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐨𝐛𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐭𝐲𝐩𝐞🛠️ 𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐨𝐥𝐲𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐦 ✅ Occurs when a parent class reference is used to call an overridden method in the child class✅ Example: Run-Time Polymorphism (via Method Over-riding) java𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑮𝒖𝒆𝒔𝒕"); }}𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒆𝒙𝒕𝒆𝒏𝒅𝒔 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 { 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆() { 𝑺𝒚𝒔𝒕𝒆𝒎.𝒐𝒖𝒕.𝒑𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒍𝒏("𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒂𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏"); }}𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒄𝒍𝒂𝒔𝒔 𝑻𝒆𝒔𝒕 { 𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄 𝒔𝒕𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒄 𝒗𝒐𝒊𝒅 𝒎𝒂𝒊𝒏(𝑺𝒕𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒈[] 𝒂𝒓𝒈𝒔) { 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋 = 𝒏𝒆𝒘 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏(); // 👈 𝑹𝒆𝒇𝒆𝒓𝒆𝒏𝒄𝒆 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆: 𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 | 𝑶𝒃𝒋𝒆𝒄𝒕 𝒕𝒚𝒑𝒆:𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏 𝒐𝒃𝒋.𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒆(); // 👈 𝑪𝒂𝒍𝒍𝒔 𝑨𝒅𝒎𝒊𝒏𝑳𝒐𝒈𝒊𝒏’𝒔 𝒎𝒆𝒕𝒉𝒐𝒅 𝒂𝒕 𝒓𝒖𝒏𝒕𝒊𝒎𝒆(𝒅𝒚𝒏𝒂𝒎𝒊𝒄 𝒃𝒊𝒏𝒅𝒊𝒏𝒈) }}

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)✅"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."🌟 What is Exception Handling?Exception handling is a way to manage errors that occur while a program is running. Instead of stopping the entire program when an error happens, exception handling lets you control what should happen when something goes wrong.🌟 Why is it important?It helps prevent the program from crashing.It allows the program to continue running even after an error.It shows clear and friendly error messages to the user.It makes debugging and fixing issues easier.🌟 How does it work?You write the code that might cause an error inside a special block. If an error happens, another block will handle it. This keeps the program safe and avoids unexpected crashes.🌟 Key Terms:Try: The block where you write the code that might cause an error.Catch: The block where you handle the error if it occurs.Finally: A block that runs no matter what—whether there was an error or not.Throw: Used to create custom errors or exceptions.Throws: Used to declare exceptions that a method might cause.

Today's Learning Journey 📕: Stacks in JavaToday, I explored one of the fundamental data structures— the Stack.**What is a Stack?** A Stack is a linear data structure that follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle. The last element added is the first one to be removed. Think of it like a stack of plates — you add to the top and remove from the top.**Why It's Important?** Stacks are used in many areas like function calls, expression evaluation, undo features in editors, and more. Understanding how they work is essential for solving real-world problems and mastering algorithms.**Key Takeaways:** 1. Core Operations: push(), pop(), peek(), and isEmpty()2. Implementation: Explored Java's built-in Stack class and also implemented it manually using arrays and linked lists. 3. Applications: Helps build intuition for recursion, backtracking, and parsing tasks.#Java #DataStructures #Stack #CodingJourney #Programming #TechLearning

كلامنا النهاردة عن  JVM، JRE، وJDK... مين هم أبطال القصة؟في عالم جافا، عندنا 3 شخصيات رئيسية، وكل واحدة ليها دور مهم جدًا:يلا نغوص سوا في عالم JVM، JRE، وJDK ونفهم كل واحدة فيهم بتشتغل إزاي؟ 🧠 أولاً: JVM – Java Virtual Machine ده هو قلب القصة.تخيله كأنه "المترجم الذكي" اللي بياخد الـ Bytecode (ملفات .class) ويحوّله لحاجة الجهاز يفهمها وظيفته:يقرأ ملفات .class اللي بيطلّعها الـ Compilerيفسرها سطر بسطر ويحوّلها لـ Machine Codeيتعامل مع نظام التشغيل (Windows / Linux / macOS)بيشتغل على أي جهاز فيه JVM → عشان كده جافا بتشتغل في كل مكان!أنواعه: كل نظام تشغيل ليه JVM خاصة بيه. الكود بيشتغل على أي نظام بشرط يكون فيه JVM.🌱 ثانيًا: JRE – Java Runtime Environment📦 دي البيئة اللي بيعيش فيها برنامج جافا بعد ما تكتبه.بتتكوّن من:JVMJava Class Libraries (زي System.out, ArrayList, Scanner, …)وظيفتها: تشغّل برامج جافا الجاهزة، بس مش ينفع تكتبي أو ترجمي كود جديد بيها. مثال: لو عندك برنامج جاهز وعايزة تشغّليه → محتاجة JRE فقط.🔧 ثالثًا: JDK – Java Development Kitدي العُدّة الكاملة لأي مطوّر/مطوّرة جافا.بتحتوي على:✅ كل مكونات الـ JRE✅ أدوات التطوير (Dev Tools):javac: لتحويل الكود لـ Bytecodejava: لتشغيل البرامجjavadoc: لتوليد التوثيقDebuggers: لتتبع الأخطاءوظيفتها:كتابة الكودترجمتهتشغيلهاختباره يعني باختصار: لو هتشتغل على مشروع جافا → لازم تنزّل الـ JDK الـ JRE لوحده مش هيكفي.لو وصلت لحد هنا، شاركني: أنت كنت عارف الفرق بينهم قبل كده؟ ولا دي أول مرة الصورة توضح؟ 😊👇hashtag#Java hashtag#JVM hashtag#JRE hashtag#JDK hashtag#LearnJava hashtag#Backend hashtag#ProgrammingBasics hashtag#لينكدإن

Maroš Varchola is a 22 year old founder based in Slovakia that builds software that processes tens of thousands of euros a month. 💸Reconciliation is the process of matching transaction data with business processes, like outgoing invoices. In the past reconciliation has been a messy, non-deterministic process, but things are changing. ISO20022 is the "HTTP" protocol of money. As banks adopt improved data formats around financial data like ISO20022, transaction matching becomes much simpler: end to end tracking IDs make reconciliation deterministic and unambigious.Maroš contributed end to end ID support to iso20022.js and uses it in production to perfectly reconcile tens of thousands of euros of invoices a month. iso20022.js is the leading library that allows developers to interact with the modern banking system. With almost a dozen contributors, it has a bigger engineering team than most startups!

🚀 Lesson Learned: Read the Docs, Save Hours! 📚⏱️While working on my final year project — a fake profile detection system using Instagram data — I spent nearly 2-3 hours trying to integrate Apify's Instagram scraper using raw API calls, handling URLs, tokens, HTTP errors… the usual grind. 😓Everything looked right, but I was constantly getting empty or default responses. Just when the frustration started to build up, I took a step back and finally did what I should have done first — I read the official Apify documentation.And guess what? 💡Turns out, Apify provides a clean and powerful Python SDK (apify-client) that makes the whole process so much easier and more reliable. Instead of manually hitting endpoints, handling dataset IDs, and parsing results, I could just:✅ Initialize the client ✅ Call the actor with run_input ✅ Iterate over results like a breezeThis experience reminded me of something simple but powerful:“Documentation is not optional — it’s a superpower.” 💥Next time, before diving into hours of trial-and-error, I’ll definitely start by checking the docs first. It’s a small habit that saves massive time.

JavaScript + XML = The Original Data Power Duo Before REST APIs returned slick JSON responses... Before fetch() made things feel magical... There was AJAX with XML — and it was revolutionary. While today we mostly use JSON, XML once ruled the web for data exchange. But here’s what’s cool: JavaScript still works smoothly with XML when needed — especially in legacy systems, enterprise integrations, and document-heavy APIs. Why XML is still relevant:Widely used in enterprise & government systemsStrong schema & validation support (XSD)Excellent for document-based dataPlays well with JavaScript via DOMParser, XMLHttpRequest, etc.Whether you're modernizing legacy platforms or diving into complex integrations, understanding XML with JavaScript gives you a serious edge.  Are you still working with XML in your projects? Standardisation of Railway signallingThere Are in principle today 3 ways of interlocking design. 1) free wired2) object oriented3) geographicalSo what defines their adavantages and disadvantages, regading Generic and Specific applications?Engineering: nr 3) provides a high amount of Generic functionality and a little part of specific engineering. Gives the supplier more work at the start, but simplifies all over time. Rating 3-2-1 in quality. Specifying SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Testing SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Resposibilities: testing of SA is typically moved back to the infrastructure manager, where 1) gives a lot of work, while 3) is reduced to a functional level. Bane NOR have chosen 3) to get a high amount of Generic functionality and Standardised Engineering for its National ERTMS L2 system, due to the totality of deliveries. Based on our experience this is the right way to go to limit amount of work and to maximise the level of standardisation of functionality throughout the network, and limits all local variants of today.
